outflank.translation[0].definitions[0].d: to gain an advantage over an opponent, especially in politics
outflank.translation[0].definitions[0].e: The Tories found themselves outflanked by Labour on the issue of law and order.
outflank.translation[0].definitions[1].d: to go around the side of a group of enemies during a battle and attack them from behind
outflank.translation[1].definitions[0].d: if one company, country etc outflanks another, it is more successful than it
outflank.translation[1].definitions[0].e: For cheaper products, the Japanese outflanked Taiwan and Korea by building factories in Southeast Asia.
It considered making a bid for the company but was outflanked by one of its competitors.
